title: 112_hr1206
content: The Act may be cited as the "Access to Professional Health Insurance Advisors Act of 2011". Licensed independent insurance producers provide a wide range of services for individuals and businesses, including acquiring quotes, analyzing plan options, and consulting clients on health insurance purchases. They also offer guidance on benefit and contribution arrangements to ensure compliance with State and Federal laws, assist with tax savings plans, and create educational materials for clients. Licensed independent insurance producers provide a variety of services such as aiding in employee benefit communication, managing eligibility, advocating for employees during the claim process, and assisting employers with insurance proposals and renewals. They are required to maintain ongoing education to stay current with the insurance market. It is crucial for them to continue fulfilling these duties to serve their clients effectively. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act has changed the regulatory environment for health plans, making professional guidance essential for employers and consumers. The National Association of Insurance Commissioners supports the role of licensed independent insurance producers in health insurance. Insurance agents and brokers play an essential role in assisting health insurance consumers during rapid market changes, and it is crucial to recognize and protect the role of licensed independent insurance producers. SEC. 3. Protecting licensed independent insurance producers to serve the public. Section 2718 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include remuneration for licensed independent insurance producers. This adjustment aims to protect licensed independent insurance producers to serve the public. The Secretary defers to State findings on destabilization. Subsection (b)(1)(B) includes remuneration for independent insurance producers. Subsection (d) now includes small group market. New subsection (f) defines independent insurance producer. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in coordination with the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, will amend regulations within 60 days to account for changes related to remuneration for insurance services.
